block.p: In ''Report by E.P.A. Leaves Out Data on Climate Change'' (front page, June 19), you suggest that the heavy-handed White House crew is keeping important information from the public. In ''Report by E.P.A. Leaves Out Data on Climate Change'' (front page, June 19), you suggest that the heavy-handed White House crew is keeping important information from the public. I believe that there is no credible information about the likely effects of climate change on Americans because the science of climate change is simply not up to the task.

Your article cites a 2001 report on climate by the National Research Council as evidence that information is being suppressed. That report tried to do the impossible: to apply the current crude climate change models to make regional projections of climate change outcomes -- droughts, floods, hurricanes and so on.
The public will benefit far more from facts on environmental challenges than from hysterical speculations.
KENNETH W. CHILTON Lake St. Louis, Mo., June 23, 2003
The writer is director, Institute for Study of Economics and the Environment, Lindenwood University.
